material-property-value-condition.content:
Please analyze the following paragraph and summarize the properties, including their numerical values, of the mentioned materials.

Paragraph: The decent hole mobilities of both copolymers can be attributed to high crystallinity of the copolymers due to the highly coplanar structure of anthracene and DPP. It is also understood that the 3-fold higher chargecarrier mobility of PTATDPP than that of PTAFDPP arises from its stronger π-π stacking with a shorter d 010 , as discussed above. When the photovoltaic properties of copolymers are measured using PC71BM as an electron acceptor , it is found that the optimum blend ratio of polymer : PC71BM is 1 : 2 to afford the best PCE of both copolymers with the conventional device architecture of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / polymer : PC71BM / Ca / Al ( Fig. S2 and Table S1 † ). The best PCE was also achieved when o-dichlorobenzene was used as a solvent and the optimum thickness for the active layer was ca. 90 nm. The current density - voltage ( J-V ) characteristics of the optimized solar cells are shown in Fig. 4 , and the relevant photovoltaic parameters of the devices are summarized in Tables 2 and S2. † PTATDPP showed a best PCE of 6.69% ( V OC = 0.80 V , J SC = 12.3 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.68 ) , while PTAFDPP showed a best PCE of 5.02% ( V OC = 0.76 V , J SC = 11.2 mA cm^-2 , FF = 0.59 ). Both copolymers showed higher V OC s than other DPP - based copolymers due to their low - lying HOMO energy levels. Both copolymers also exhibited high J SC s and FFs , indicating their decent ability for charge generation and transport. Therefore , the TA unit is a promising electron - donating unit for low band - gap copolymers with a low - lying HOMO energy level. When the PSC devices were fabricated with an inverted architecture ( ITO / ZnO / polymer : PC71BM / MoO 3 / Ag ) in order to further improve the photovoltaic performance , the PCEs of PTATDPP and PTAFDPP - based devices were improved to 7.02% and 5.22% , respectively ( Fig. 4b , Tables 2 and S2 † ) , mainly due to enhanced J SC s ( V OC s and FFs were not changed significantly ). It is noteworthy here that the PCE of over 7% of PTATDPP is the highest efficiency of anthracene - based low band - gap conjugated copolymers. In spite of the same band - gap of the two copolymers , PTATDPP shows slightly higher J SC and FF than PTAFDPP ( Fig. S3 † ). This can be ascribed to the closely packed microstructures of PTATDPP and thereby its high charge - carrier mobility than PTAFDPP. When the crystal structures of blend films of the copolymers with PC71BM were examined by XRD , the PTATDPP / PC71BM blend had strong and intense ( 100 ) diffraction while the PTAFDPP / PC71BM blend showed weak and broad ( 100 ) diffraction ( Fig. 2b ).

Let's think step by step.

1. The paragraph discusses the properties of two copolymers, PTATDPP and PTAFDPP, and their use in organic solar cells.
2. The copolymers have a high crystallinity due to the highly coplanar structure of anthracene and DPP.
3. The charge-carrier mobility of PTATDPP is higher than that of PTAFDPP due to its stronger π-π stacking with a shorter d010.
4. The optimum blend ratio of polymer to PC71BM for the best photovoltaic performance is 1:2.
5. The best PCE (power conversion efficiency) was achieved with o-dichlorobenzene as a solvent and an active layer thickness of ca. 90 nm.
6. PTATDPP showed a best PCE of 6.69% with VOC = 0.80 V, JSC = 12.3 mA cm^-2, and FF = 0.68, while PTAFDPP showed a best PCE of 5.02% with VOC = 0.76 V, JSC = 11.2 mA cm^-2, and FF = 0.59.
7. Both copolymers showed high VOCs than other DPP-based copolymers due to their low-lying HOMO energy levels.
8. Both copolymers also exhibited high JSCs and FFs, indicating their decent ability for charge generation and transport.
9. The PCEs of PTATDPP and PTAFDPP-based devices were improved to 7.02% and 5.22%, respectively, with an inverted architecture.
10. PTATDPP shows slightly higher JSC and FF than PTAFDPP, which can be attributed to its closely packed microstructures and high charge-carrier mobility.
11. The crystal structures of blend films of the copolymers with PC71BM were examined by XRD, and PTATDPP/PC71BM blend had strong and intense (100) diffraction, while PTAFDPP/PC71BM blend showed weak and broad (100) diffraction.

Numerical values:

* PCE: 6.69% (PTATDPP), 5.02% (PTAFDPP)
* VOC: 0.80 V (PTATDPP), 0.76 V (PTAFDPP)
* JSC: 12.3 mA cm^-2 (PTATDPP), 11.2 mA cm^-2 (PTAFDPP)
* FF: 0.68 (PTATDPP), 0.59 (PTAFDPP)
* d010: shorter (PTATDPP)
* Optimum blend ratio: 1:2 (PTATDPP and PTAFDPP)
* Active layer thickness: ca. 90 nm
* Solvent: o-dichlorobenzene

Note: The numerical values are based on the information provided in the paragraph and may not be a comprehensive list of all numerical values mentioned.

If exists, please present the valid relationships as a Markdown table with columns "['Material Name', 'Material Property', 'Material Property (Abbr.)', 'Numerical Value', 'Condition']". Make sure the table items are from the original paragraph.

| Material Name | Material Property | Material Property (Abbr.) | Numerical Value | Condition |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| PTATDPP | Charge-carrier mobility | - | 3-fold higher | - |
| PTATDPP | HOMO energy level | HOMO | low-lying | - |
| PTAFDPP | Charge-carrier mobility | - | lower than PTATDPP | - |
| PTAFDPP | HOMO energy level | HOMO | low-lying | - |
| PTATDPP/PC71BM blend | Diffraction | (100) | strong and intense | XRD |
| PTAFDPP/PC71BM blend | Diffraction | (100) | weak and broad | XRD |

Note: The "Condition" column provides a brief description of the condition under which the numerical value was observed or the method used to measure the property.
